{{short description|Analysis of datasets using techniques from topology}} In [[applied mathematics]], '''topological data analysis''' ('''TDA''') is an approach to the analysis of datasets using techniques from [[topology]]. Extraction of information from datasets that are high-dimensional, incomplete and noisy is generally challenging. TDA provides a general framework to analyze such data in a manner that is insensitive to the particular [[metric (mathematics)|metric]] chosen and provides [[dimensionality reduction]] and robustness to noise. Beyond this, it inherits [[functor]]iality, a fundamental concept of modern mathematics, from its topological nature, which allows it to adapt to new mathematical tools.
The initial motivation is to study the shape of data. TDA has combined [[algebraic topology]] and other tools from pure mathematics to allow mathematically rigorous study of "shape". The main tool is [[persistent homology]], an adaptation of [[Homology (mathematics)|homology]] to [[point cloud]] data. Persistent homology has been applied to many types of data across many fields. Moreover, its mathematical foundation is also of theoretical importance. The unique features of TDA make it a promising bridge between topology and geometry.
== Basic theory ==
=== Intuition === {{tone}} The premise underlying TDA is that shape matters. Real data in high dimensions is nearly always sparse, and tends to have relevant low dimensional features. One task of TDA is to provide a precise characterization of this fact. An illustrative example is a simple predator-prey system governed by the [[Lotka–Volterra equations]].<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Topological data analysis|url = http://iopscience.iop.org/article/10.1088/0266-5611/27/12/120201|journal = Inverse Problems|date = 2011-12-01|volume = 27|issue = 12|doi = 10.1088/0266-5611/27/12/120201|first = Charles|last = Epstein|author1-link=Charles Epstein|first2 = Gunnar|last2 = Carlsson|author2-link=Gunnar Carlsson|first3 = Herbert|last3 = Edelsbrunner|author3-link=Herbert Edelsbrunner|pages=120201|arxiv = 1609.08227|bibcode = 2011InvPr..27a0101E}}</ref> One can easily observe that the trajectory of the system forms a closed circle in state space. TDA provides tools to detect and quantify such recurrent motion.<ref>{{Cite web|title=diva-portal.org/smash/record.jsf?pid=diva2%253A575329&dswid=4297 |url=http://www.diva-portal.org/smash/record.jsf?pid=diva2%253A575329&dswid=4297 |website=www.diva-portal.org |accessdate=2015-11-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151119021029/http://www.diva-portal.org/smash/record.jsf?pid=diva2%3A575329 |archivedate=November 19, 2015 }}</ref>
Many algorithms for data analysis, including those used in TDA, require the choice of various parameters. Without prior domain knowledge, the correct collection of parameters for a data set is difficult to choose. The main insight of [[persistent homology]] is that we can use the information obtained from all values of a parameter. Of course this insight alone is easy to make; the hard part is encoding this huge amount of information into an understandable and easy-to-represent form. With TDA, there is a mathematical interpretation when the information is a homology group. In general, the assumption is that features that persist for a wide range of parameters are "true" features. Features persisting for only a narrow range of parameters are presumed to be noise, although the theoretical justification for this is unclear.<ref name=":4" />
=== Early history === Precursors to the full concept of persistent homology appeared gradually over time.<ref name=":19">Edelsbrunner H. Persistent homology: theory and practice[J]. 2014.</ref> In 1990, Patrizio Frosini introduced the size function, which is equivalent to the 0th persistent homology.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = A distance for similarity classes of submanifolds of a Euclidean space|url = http://journals.cambridge.org/article_S0004972700028574|journal = Bulletin of the Australian Mathematical Society|date = 1990-12-01|issn = 1755-1633|pages = 407–415|volume = 42|issue = 03|doi = 10.1017/S0004972700028574|first = Patrizio|last = Frosini}}</ref> Nearly a decade later, Vanessa Robins studied the images of homomorphisms induced by inclusion.<ref>Robins V. Towards computing homology from finite approximations[C]//Topology proceedings. 1999, 24(1): 503-532.</ref> Finally, shortly thereafter, Edelsbrunner et al. introduced the concept of persistent homology together with an efficient algorithm and its visualization as a persistence diagram.<ref name=":7">{{Cite journal|title = Topological Persistence and Simplification|url = https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s00454-002-2885-2|journal = Discrete & Computational Geometry|date = 2002-11-01|issn = 0179-5376|pages = 511–533|volume = 28|issue = 4|doi = 10.1007/s00454-002-2885-2}}</ref> Carlsson et al. reformulated the initial definition and gave an equivalent visualization method called persistence barcodes,<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Persistence barcodes for shapes|url = http://www.worldscientific.com/doi/abs/10.1142/S0218654305000761|journal = International Journal of Shape Modeling|date = 2005-12-01|issn = 0218-6543|pages = 149–187|volume = 11|issue = 02|doi = 10.1142/S0218654305000761|first = Gunnar|last = Carlsson|first2 = Afra|last2 = Zomorodian|first3 = Anne|last3 = Collins|first4 = Leonidas J.|last4 = Guibas}}</ref> interpreting persistence in the language of commutative algebra.<ref name=":1" />
In algebraic topology, the set of critical values of smooth Morse function was canonically partitioned into pairs "birth-death", filtered complexes were classified and the visualization of their invariants, equivalent to persistence diagram and persistence barcodes, was given in 1994 by Barannikov's canonical form<ref name="Barannikov 1994">{{Cite journal|title = Framed Morse complex and its invariants |url = https://www.researchgate.net/publication/267672645_The_Framed_Morse_complex_and_its_invariants |journal = Advances in Soviet Mathematics | date = 1994|pages = 93–115|volume = 21|first = Sergey|last = Barannikov}}</ref>.
=== Concepts === Some widely used concepts are introduced below. Note that some definitions may vary from author to author.
A '''[[point cloud]]''' is often defined as a finite set of points in some Euclidean space, but may be taken to be any finite metric space.
The [[Cech complex|'''Čech complex''']] of a point cloud is the [[Nerve of a covering|''nerve'' of the ''cover'']] of balls of a fixed radius around each point in the cloud.
A '''persistence module''' <math>\mathbb{U}</math> indexed by <math>\mathbb{Z}</math> is a vector space <math>U_t</math> for each <math>t \in \mathrm{Z}</math>, and a linear map <math>u_t^s: U_s \to U_t</math> whenever <math>s \leq t</math>, such that <math>u_t^t=1</math> for all <math>t</math> and <math>u_t^su_s^r=u_t^r</math> whenever <math>r \leq s \leq t.</math><ref name=":11">{{Cite journal|title = Proximity of Persistence Modules and Their Diagrams|url = http://doi.acm.org/10.1145/1542362.1542407|publisher = ACM|journal = Proceedings of the Twenty-fifth Annual Symposium on Computational Geometry|date = 2009-01-01|location = New York, NY, USA|isbn = 978-1-60558-501-7|pages = 237–246|series = SCG '09|doi = 10.1145/1542362.1542407|first = Frédéric|last = Chazal|first2 = David|last2 = Cohen-Steiner|first3 = Marc|last3 = Glisse|first4 = Leonidas J.|last4 = Guibas|first5 = Steve Y.|last5 = Oudot}}</ref> An equivalent definition is a functor from <math>\mathbb{Z}</math> considered as a partially ordered set to the category of vector spaces.
The '''persistent homology group''' <math>PH</math> of a point cloud is the persistence module defined as <math>PH_k(X)= \prod H_k(X_r)</math>, where <math>X_r</math> is the Čech complex of radius <math>r</math> of the point cloud <math>X</math> and <math>H_k</math> is the homology group.
A '''persistence barcode''' is a [[Multiset (abstract data type)|multiset]] of intervals in <math>\mathbb{R}</math>, and a '''persistence diagram''' is a multiset of points in <math>\Delta</math>(<math>:= \{(u,v) \in \mathbb{R}^2| u,v \geq 0, u \leq v\}</math>).
The [[Wasserstein metric|'''Wasserstein distance''']] between two persistence diagrams <math>X</math> and <math>Y</math> is defined as <math display="block">W_p[L_q](X,Y):= \inf_{\phi: X \to Y} [~\sum_{x \in X} \Vert x-\phi(x)\Vert _q~]^{\frac{1}{p}}</math>where <math>1 \leq p,q \leq \infty</math> and <math>\phi</math> ranges over bijections between <math>X</math> and <math>Y</math>. Please refer to figure 3.1 in Munch <ref>Munch E. Applications of persistent homology to time varying systems[D]. Duke University, 2013.</ref> for illustration.
The '''bottleneck distance''' between <math>X</math> and <math>Y</math> is <math display="block">W_{\infty}[L_q](X,Y):= \inf_{\phi: X \to Y} \sup_{x \in X} \Vert x-\phi(x)\Vert _q.</math> This is a special case of Wasserstein distance, letting <math>p=\infty</math>.
=== Basic property ===
==== Structure theorem ==== The first classification theorem for persistent homology appeared in 2005:<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|title = Computing Persistent Homology|url = https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s00454-004-1146-y|journal = Discrete & Computational Geometry|date = 2004-11-19|issn = 0179-5376|pages = 249–274|volume = 33|issue = 2|doi = 10.1007/s00454-004-1146-y|first = Afra|last = Zomorodian|first2 = Gunnar|last2 = Carlsson}}</ref> for a finitely generated persistence module <math>C</math> with field <math>F</math> coefficients, <math display="block">H(C;F) \simeq \bigoplus_i x^{t_i} \cdot F[x] \oplus \left(\bigoplus_j x^{r_j} \cdot (F[x]/(x^{s_j}\cdot F[x]))\right).</math> Intuitively, the free parts correspond to the homology generators that appear at filtration level <math>t_i</math> and never disappear, while the torsion parts correspond to those that appear at filtration level <math>r_j</math> and last for <math>s_j</math> steps of the filtration (or equivalently, disappear at filtration level <math>s_j+r_j</math>)<ref name="Barannikov 1994"/>.
Persistent homology is visualized through a barcode or persistence diagram. The barcode has its root in abstract mathematics, though not at first sight; essentially, the derived category of chain complexes over a field is equivalent to the graded category of vector spaces.<ref>{{Cite book|title = An Introduction to Homological Algebra|url = https://books.google.com/books?hl=zh-CN&lr=&id=flm-dBXfZ_gC&oi=fnd&pg=PR11&dq=weibel+homological&ots=_MbUFbYFtd&sig=blH5vOFonrO8auLT8uOnKQ-_uRU#v=onepage&q=weibel%2520homological&f=false|publisher = Cambridge University Press|date = 1995-10-27|isbn = 9780521559874|first = Charles A.|last = Weibel}}</ref>
==== Stability ==== Stability is desirable because it provides robustness against noise. If <math>X</math> is any space which is homeomorphic to a simplicial complex, and <math>f,g:X\to \mathbb{R}</math> are continuous tame<ref name="Shikhman">{{cite book|last1=Shikhman|first1=Vladimir|title=Topological Aspects of Nonsmooth Optimization|date=2011|publisher=Springer Science & Business Media|isbn=9781461418979|pages=169-170|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_D4FL3i4vIQC&pg=PA169&lpg=PA169&dq=%22tame+set%22+semialgebraic&source=bl&ots=fTSSDvXsbN&sig=9kym0Q8OHpS7l-ZTA_Xck5icdDM&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjQxoe0i9LXAhXIgVQKHRXeCtQQ6AEIYzAI#v=onepage&q=%22tame%20set%22%20semialgebraic&f=false|accessdate=22 November 2017|language=en}}</ref> functions, then the persistence vector spaces <math>\{H_k(f^{-1}([0,r]))\}</math> and <math>\{H_k(g^{-1}([0,r]))\}</math> are finitely presented, and <math>W_{\infty}(D(f),D(g)) \leq \lVert f-g \rVert_{\infty}</math>, where <math>W_{\infty}</math> refers to the bottleneck distance<ref name=":17">{{Cite journal|title = Stability of Persistence Diagrams|url = https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s00454-006-1276-5|journal = Discrete & Computational Geometry|date = 2006-12-12|issn = 0179-5376|pages = 103–120|volume = 37|issue = 1|doi = 10.1007/s00454-006-1276-5|first = David|last = Cohen-Steiner|first2 = Herbert|last2 = Edelsbrunner|first3 = John|last3 = Harer}}</ref> and <math>D</math> is the map taking a continuous tame function to the persistence diagram of its <math>k</math>-th homology.
=== Workflow === The basic workflow in TDA is:<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Barcodes: The persistent topology of data|url = http://www.ams.org/bull/2008-45-01/S0273-0979-07-01191-3/|journal = Bulletin of the American Mathematical Society|date = 2008-01-01|issn = 0273-0979|pages = 61–75|volume = 45|issue = 1|doi = 10.1090/S0273-0979-07-01191-3|first = Robert|last = Ghrist}}</ref> {| class="wikitable" |point cloud |<math>\to</math> |nested complexes |<math>\to</math> |persistence module |<math>\to</math> |barcode or diagram |} # If <math>X</math> is a point cloud, replace <math>X</math> with a nested family of [[simplicial complex]]es <math>X_{r}</math> (such as the Čech or Vietoris-Rips complex). This process converts the point cloud into a filtration of simplicial complexes. Taking the homology of each complex in this filtration gives a persistence module <math display="block">H_i(X_{r_0})\to H_i(X_{r_1}) \to H_i(X_{r_2}) \to \cdots</math> # Apply the structure theorem to provide a parameterized version of [[Betti number]], '''persistence diagram,''' or equivalently, '''barcode.''' Graphically speaking, [[File:Illustration of Typical Workflow in TDA.jpeg|thumb|488x488px|A usual use of persistence in TDA <ref>{{cite arXiv|title = Optimal rates of convergence for persistence diagrams in Topological Data Analysis|arxiv= 1305.6239|date = 2013-05-27|first = Frédéric|last = Chazal|first2 = Marc|last2 = Glisse|first3 = Catherine|last3 = Labruère|first4 = Bertrand|last4 = Michel}}</ref>|centre]]
== Computation == The first algorithm for persistent homology over <math>F_2</math> was given by Edelsbrunner et al.<ref name=":7" /> Zomorodian and Carlsson gave the first practical algorithm to compute persistent homology over all fields.<ref name=":1" /> Edelsbrunner and Harer's book gives general guidance on computational topology.<ref name=":14">{{Cite book|title = Computational Topology: An Introduction|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=MDXa6gFRZuIC|publisher = American Mathematical Soc.|date = 2010-01-01|isbn = 9780821849255|first = Herbert|last = Edelsbrunner|first2 = John|last2 = Harer}}</ref>
One issue that arises in computation is the choice of complex. The [[Čech cohomology|Čech complex]] and [[Vietoris–Rips complex|Vietoris-Rips complex]] are most natural at first glance; however, their size grows rapidly with the number of data points. The Vietoris-Rips complex is preferred over Čech complex because its definition is simpler and the Čech complex requires extra effort to define in a general finite metric space. Efficient ways to lower the computational cost of homology have been studied. For example, the α-complex and witness complex are used to reduce the dimension and size of complexes.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Topological Estimation Using Witness Complexes|publisher = Eurographics Association|journal = Proceedings of the First Eurographics Conference on Point-Based Graphics|date = 2004-01-01|location = Aire-la-Ville, Switzerland, Switzerland|isbn = 3-905673-09-6|pages = 157–166|series = SPBG'04|doi = 10.2312/SPBG/SPBG04/157-166|first = Vin|last = De Silva|first2 = Gunnar|last2 = Carlsson}}</ref>
Recently, [[Discrete Morse theory]] has shown promise for computational homology because it can reduce a given simplicial complex to a much smaller cellular complex which is homotopic to the original one.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Morse Theory for Filtrations and Efficient Computation of Persistent Homology|url = https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s00454-013-9529-6|journal = Discrete & Computational Geometry|date = 2013-07-27|issn = 0179-5376|pages = 330–353|volume = 50|issue = 2|doi = 10.1007/s00454-013-9529-6|first = Konstantin|last = Mischaikow|first2 = Vidit|last2 = Nanda}}</ref> This reduction can in fact be performed as the complex is constructed by using [[Matroid|matroid theory]], leading to further performance increases.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Henselman|first1=Gregory|last2=Ghrist|first2=Robert|title=Matroid Filtrations and Computational Persistent Homology|date=1 Jun 2016|arxiv=1606.00199|bibcode=2016arXiv160600199H}}</ref> Another recent algorithm saves time by ignoring the homology classes with low persistence.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = An output-sensitive algorithm for persistent homology|url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0925772112001435|journal = Computational Geometry|date = 2013-05-01|pages = 435–447|volume = 46|series = 27th Annual Symposium on Computational Geometry (SoCG 2011)|issue = 4|doi = 10.1016/j.comgeo.2012.02.010|first = Chao|last = Chen|first2 = Michael|last2 = Kerber}}</ref>
Various software packages are available, such as [https://code.google.com/p/javaplex/ javaPlex], [http://www.mrzv.org/software/dionysus/ Dionysus], [http://www.sas.upenn.edu/~vnanda/perseus/index.html Perseus], [http://phat.googlecode.com/ PHAT], [https://github.com/DIPHA/dipha/ DIPHA], [https://project.inria.fr/gudhi/software/ Gudhi], [https://github.com/Ripser/ripser Ripser], and [https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=TDAstats TDAstats]. A comparison between these tools is done by Otter et al.<ref>{{cite arXiv|title = A roadmap for the computation of persistent homology|arxiv= 1506.08903|date = 2015-06-29|first = Nina|last = Otter|first2 = Mason A.|last2 = Porter|first3 = Ulrike|last3 = Tillmann|first4 = Peter|last4 = Grindrod|first5 = Heather A.|last5 = Harrington|author5-link=Heather Harrington}}</ref> An R package [https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/TDA/index.html TDA] is capable of calculating recently invented concepts like landscape and the kernel distance estimator.<ref>{{cite arXiv|title = Introduction to the R package TDA|arxiv= 1411.1830|date = 2014-11-07|first = Brittany Terese|last = Fasy|first2 = Jisu|last2 = Kim|first3 = Fabrizio|last3 = Lecci|first4 = Clément|last4 = Maria}}</ref> The [https://topology-tool-kit.github.io/ Topology ToolKit] is specialized for continuous data defined on manifolds of low dimension (1, 2 or 3), as typically found in [[scientific visualization]]. Also, a recently released R package, [https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=TDAstats TDAstats], implements the fast C++ Ripser library to calculate persistent homology.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = TDAstats: R pipeline for computing persistent homology in topological data analysis|url = http://joss.theoj.org/papers/10.21105/joss.00860|journal = Journal of Open Source Software|date = 2018|pages=860|volume = 3|issue = 28|doi = 10.21105/joss.00860|first = Raoul|last = Wadhwa|first2 = Drew|last2 = Williamson|first3 = Andrew|last3 = Dhawan|first4 = Jacob|last4 = Scott}}</ref> It also uses the ubiquitous [https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=ggplot2 ggplot2] package to generate reproducible, customizable, publication-quality visualizations of persistent homology, specifically topological barcodes and persistence diagrams. The sample code below gives an example of how the [[R programming language]] can be used to compute persistent homology.
<source lang="R"> # install TDAstats package from CRAN and load install.packages("TDAstats") library("TDAstats")
# make code reproducible set.seed(1)
# create dataset: point cloud with 100 2-dimensional uniformly distributed points in a unit square unif.2d <- cbind(runif(100), runif(100))
# create dataset: 100-points on a circle in 2 dimensions angles <- runif(100, 0, 2 * pi) circ.2d <- cbind(cos(angles), sin(angles))
# calculate persistent homology for both datasets # dim = 1 is maximum dimension of cycles for 2-dimensional data; increase # appropriately for larger dimensions (dim := dimension - 1) unif.hom <- calculate_homology(unif.2d, dim = 1) circ.hom <- calculate_homology(circ.2d, dim = 1)
# plot uniformly distributed point cloud as persistence diagram # although some features might look significant, the units on this diagram # and the following barcode will clarify that all the features in this diagram # are pretty short/represent noise plot_persist(unif.hom)
# plot circle point cloud as topological barcode # we see a single persistent bar, as expected for a circle (single 1-cycle/loop) plot_barcode(circ.hom) </source>
[[File:Persistence Diagram.png|thumb|Persistence diagram created by sample code (unif.2d dataset) for a set of 100 points uniformly distributed within a 2-dimensional unit square. None of the 0-cycles or 1-cycles are considered true signal (none truly exist within a unit square point cloud). Although some features appear to persist, the axis ticks show that the most persistent feature persists for less than 0.20 units, which is relatively small for a point cloud on a unit square.]]
[[File:Topological Barcode.png|thumb|Topological barcode created by sample code (circ.2d dataset) for a set of 100 points uniformly distributed around the circumference of a circle. The single, long 1-dimensional feature at the top of the barcode represents the only 1-cycle present in a circle.]]
==Visualization== High-dimensional data is impossible to visualize directly. Many methods have been invented to extract a low-dimensional structure from the data set, such as [[principal component analysis]] and [[multidimensional scaling]].<ref>Liu S, Maljovec D, Wang B, et al. Visualizing High-Dimensional Data: Advances in the Past Decade[J].</ref> However, it is important to note that the problem itself is ill-posed, since many different topological features can be found in the same data set. Thus, the study of visualization of high-dimensional spaces is of central importance to TDA, although it does not necessarily involve the use of persistent homology. However, recent attempts have been made to use persistent homology in data visualization.<ref name=":15" />
Carlsson et al. have proposed a general method called '''MAPPER'''.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|title = Download Limit Exceeded|url = http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?doi=10.1.1.161.8956&rep=rep1&type=pdf|website = citeseerx.ist.psu.edu|accessdate = 2015-11-02}}</ref> It inherits the idea of Serre that a covering preserves homotopy.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Differential Forms in Algebraic Topology|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=COuPBAAAQBAJ|publisher = Springer Science & Business Media|date = 2013-04-17|isbn = 9781475739510|first = Raoul|last = Bott|first2 = Loring W.|last2 = Tu}}</ref> A generalized formulation of MAPPER is as follows:
Let <math>X</math> and <math>Z</math> be topological spaces and let <math>f:X\to Z</math> be a continuous map. Let <math>\mathbb{U} = \{U_{\alpha}\}_{\alpha \in A}</math> be a finite open covering of <math>Z</math>. The output of MAPPER is the nerve of the pullback cover <math display="inline">M(\mathbb{U},f):=N(f^{-1}(\mathbb{U}))</math>, where each preimage is split into its connected components.<ref name=":15">{{cite arXiv|title = Mutiscale Mapper: A Framework for Topological Summarization of Data and Maps|arxiv= 1504.03763|date = 2015-04-14|first = Tamal K.|last = Dey|first2 = Facundo|last2 = Memoli|first3 = Yusu|last3 = Wang}}</ref> This is a very general concept, of which the Reeb graph and merge trees are special cases.
This is not quite the original definition.<ref name=":2" /> Carlsson et al. choose <math>Z</math> to be <math>\mathbb{R}</math> or <math>\mathbb{R}^2</math>, and cover it with open sets such that at most two intersect.<ref name=":4" /> This restriction means that the output is in the form of a [[complex network]]. Because the topology of a finite point cloud is trivial, clustering methods (such as [[Single-linkage clustering|single linkage]]) are used to produce the analogue of connected sets in the preimage <math>f^{-1}(U)</math> when MAPPER is applied to actual data.
Mathematically speaking, MAPPER is a variation of the [[Reeb graph]]. If the <math display="inline">M(\mathbb{U},f)</math> is at most one dimensional, then for each <math>i \geq 0</math>, <math display="block">H_i(X) \simeq H_0(N(\mathbb{U});\hat{F}_i) \oplus H_1(N(\mathbb{U});\hat{F}_{i-1}).</math><ref>{{cite arXiv|title = Sheaves, Cosheaves and Applications|arxiv= 1303.3255|date = 2013-03-13|first = Justin|last = Curry}}</ref> The added flexibility also has disadvantages. One problem is instability, in that some change of the choice of the cover can lead to major change of the output of the algorithm.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = A fast algorithm for constructing topological structure in large data|url = http://projecteuclid.org/euclid.hha/1355321072|journal = Homology, Homotopy and Applications|date = 2012-01-01|issn = 1532-0073|pages = 221–238|volume = 14|issue = 1|first = Xu|last = Liu|first2 = Zheng|last2 = Xie|first3 = Dongyun|last3 = Yi|doi=10.4310/hha.2012.v14.n1.a11}}</ref> Work has been done to overcome this problem.<ref name=":15"/>
Three successful applications of MAPPER can be found in Carlsson et al.<ref name=":10">{{Cite journal|title = Extracting insights from the shape of complex data using topology|url = http://www.nature.com/articles/srep01236?message-global=remove&WT.ec_id=SREP-639-20130301|journal = Scientific Reports|date = 2013-02-07|pmc = 3566620|pmid = 23393618|volume = 3|doi = 10.1038/srep01236|first = P. Y.|last = Lum|first2 = G.|last2 = Singh|first3 = A.|last3 = Lehman|first4 = T.|last4 = Ishkanov|first5 = M.|last5 = Vejdemo-Johansson|first6 = M.|last6 = Alagappan|first7 = J.|last7 = Carlsson|first8 = G.|last8 = Carlsson|bibcode = 2013NatSR...3E1236L}}</ref> A comment on the applications in this paper by J. Curry is that "a common feature of interest in applications is the presence of flares or tendrils."<ref name=":3">{{cite arXiv|title = Topological Data Analysis and Cosheaves|arxiv= 1411.0613|date = 2014-11-03|first = Justin|last = Curry}}</ref>
A free implementation of MAPPER is available [http://danifold.net/mapper/ online] written by Daniel Müllner and Aravindakshan Babu. MAPPER also forms the basis of [[Ayasdi]]'s AI platform.
=== Multidimensional persistence === Multidimensional persistence is important to TDA. The concept arises in both theory and practice. The first investigation of multidimensional persistence was early in the development of TDA,<ref>Frosini P, Mulazzani M. Size homotopy groups for computation of natural size distances[J]. Bulletin of the Belgian Mathematical Society Simon Stevin, 1999, 6(3): 455-464.</ref> and is one of the founding papers of TDA.<ref name=":1" /> The first application to appear in the literature is a method for shape comparison, similar to the invention of TDA.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Multidimensional Size Functions for Shape Comparison|url = https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10851-008-0096-z|journal = Journal of Mathematical Imaging and Vision|date = 2008-05-17|issn = 0924-9907|pages = 161–179|volume = 32|issue = 2|doi = 10.1007/s10851-008-0096-z|first = S.|last = Biasotti|first2 = A.|last2 = Cerri|first3 = P.|last3 = Frosini|first4 = D.|last4 = Giorgi|first5 = C.|last5 = Landi}}</ref>
The definition of an '''''n''-dimensional persistence module''' in <math>\mathbb{R}^n</math> is<ref name=":3" /> * vector space <math>V_s</math> is assigned to each point in <math>s=(s_1,...,s_n)</math> * map <math>\rho_s^t:V_s \to V_t</math> is assigned if <math>s\leq t</math>(<math>s_i \leq t_i, i=1,...,n)</math> * maps satisfy <math>\rho_r^t=\rho_s^t \circ \rho_r^s</math> for all <math>r \leq s \leq t</math> It might be worth noting that there are controversies on the definition of multidimensional persistence.<ref name=":3" />
One of the advantages of one-dimensional persistence is its representability by a diagram or barcode. However, discrete complete invariants of multidimensional persistence modules do not exist.<ref name="Carlsson 71–93">{{Cite journal|title = The Theory of Multidimensional Persistence|url = https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s00454-009-9176-0|journal = Discrete & Computational Geometry|date = 2009-04-24|issn = 0179-5376|pages = 71–93|volume = 42|issue = 1|doi = 10.1007/s00454-009-9176-0|first = Gunnar|last = Carlsson|first2 = Afra|last2 = Zomorodian}}</ref> The main reason for this is that the structure of the collection of indecomposables is extremely complicated by [[Gabriel's theorem]] in the theory of quiver representations,<ref>Derksen H, Weyman J. Quiver representations[J]. Notices of the AMS, 2005, 52(2): 200-206.</ref> although a finitely n-dim persistence module can be uniquely decomposed into a direct sum of indecomposables due to the Krull-Schmidt theorem.<ref>Atiyah M F. On the Krull-Schmidt theorem with application to sheaves[J]. Bulletin de la Société Mathématique de France, 1956, 84: 307-317.</ref>
Nonetheless, many results have been established. Carlsson and Zomorodian introduced the '''rank invariant''' <math>\rho_M(u,v)</math>, defined as the <math>\rho_M(u,v)=\mathrm{rank}(x^{u-v}:M_u\to M_v)</math>, in which <math>M</math> is a finitely generated n-graded module. In one dimension, it is equivalent to the barcode. In the literature, the rank invariant is often referred as the persistent Betti numbers (PBNs).<ref name=":14" /> In many theoretical works, authors have used a more restricted definition, an analogue from sublevel set persistence. Specifically, the persistence Betti numbers of a function <math>f:X\to \mathrm{R}^k</math> are given by the function <math>\beta_f: \Delta^{+} \to \mathrm{N}</math>, taking each <math>(u,v) \in \Delta^{+}</math> to <math>\beta_f(u,v):= \mathrm{rank} (H(X(f\leq u)\to H(X(f\leq v)))</math>, where <math>\Delta^{+} := \{(u,v)\in \mathbb{R}\times\mathbb{R}:u\leq v\}</math> and <math>X(f\leq u):=\{x\in X:f(x)\leq u\}</math>.
Some basic properties include monotonicity and diagonal jump.<ref>Cerri A, Di Fabio B, Ferri M, et al. Multidimensional persistent homology is stable[J]. {{arxiv|0908.0064}}, 2009.</ref> Persistent Betti numbers will be finite if <math>X</math> is a compact and locally contractible subspace of <math>\mathbb{R}^n</math>.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Finiteness of rank invariants of multidimensional persistent homology groups|url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0893965910004118|journal = Applied Mathematics Letters|date = 2011-04-01|pages = 516–518|volume = 24|issue = 4|doi = 10.1016/j.aml.2010.11.004|first = Francesca|last = Cagliari|first2 = Claudia|last2 = Landi|arxiv = 1001.0358}}</ref>
Using a foliation method, the k-dim PBNs can be decomposed into a family of 1-dim PBNs by dimensionality deduction.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = One-dimensional reduction of multidimensional persistent homology|url = http://www.ams.org/proc/2010-138-08/S0002-9939-10-10312-8/|journal = Proceedings of the American Mathematical Society|date = 2010-01-01|issn = 0002-9939|pages = 3003–3017|volume = 138|issue = 8|doi = 10.1090/S0002-9939-10-10312-8|first = Francesca|last = Cagliari|first2 = Barbara|last2 = Di Fabio|first3 = Massimo|last3 = Ferri|arxiv = math/0702713}}</ref> This method has also led to a proof that multi-dim PBNs are stable.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Betti numbers in multidimensional persistent homology are stable functions|url = http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/mma.2704/abstract|journal = Mathematical Methods in the Applied Sciences|date = 2013-08-01|issn = 1099-1476|pages = 1543–1557|volume = 36|issue = 12|doi = 10.1002/mma.2704|first = Andrea|last = Cerri|first2 = Barbara Di|last2 = Fabio|first3 = Massimo|last3 = Ferri|first4 = Patrizio|last4 = Frosini|first5 = Claudia|last5 = Landi|bibcode = 2013MMAS...36.1543C}}</ref> The discontinuities of PBNs only occur at points <math>(u,v) (u\leq v)</math> where either <math>u</math> is a discontinuous point of <math>\rho_M (\star,v)</math> or <math>v</math> is a discontinuous point of <math>\rho (u,\star)</math> under the assumption that <math>f\in C^0(X,\mathrm{R}^k)</math> and <math>X</math> is a compact, triangulable topological space.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Necessary conditions for discontinuities of multidimensional persistent Betti numbers|url = http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/mma.3093/abstract|journal = Mathematical Methods in the Applied Sciences|date = 2015-03-15|issn = 1099-1476|pages = 617–629|volume = 38|issue = 4|doi = 10.1002/mma.3093|first = Andrea|last = Cerri|first2 = Patrizio|last2 = Frosini|bibcode = 2015MMAS...38..617C}}</ref>
Persistent space, a generalization of persistent diagram, is defined as the multiset of all points with multiplicity larger than 0 and the diagonal.<ref>{{Cite book|title = The Persistence Space in Multidimensional Persistent Homology|url = https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-3-642-37067-0_16|publisher = Springer Berlin Heidelberg|date = 2013-03-20|isbn = 978-3-642-37066-3|pages = 180–191|series = Lecture Notes in Computer Science|doi = 10.1007/978-3-642-37067-0_16|first = Andrea|last = Cerri|first2 = Claudia|last2 = Landi|editor-first = Rocio|editor-last = Gonzalez-Diaz|editor-first2 = Maria-Jose|editor-last2 = Jimenez|editor-first3 = Belen|editor-last3 = Medrano}}</ref> It provides a stable and complete representation of PBNs. An ongoing work by Carlsson et al. is trying to give geometric interpretation of persistent homology, which might provide insights on how to combine machine learning theory with topological data analysis.<ref>{{cite arXiv|title = Numeric Invariants from Multidimensional Persistence|arxiv= 1411.4022|date = 2014-11-14|first = Jacek|last = Skryzalin|first2 = Gunnar|last2 = Carlsson}}</ref>
The first practical algorithm to compute multidimensional persistence was invented very early.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Computing Multidimensional Persistence|url = https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-3-642-10631-6_74|publisher = Springer Berlin Heidelberg|date = 2009-12-16|isbn = 978-3-642-10630-9|pages = 730–739|series = Lecture Notes in Computer Science|doi = 10.1007/978-3-642-10631-6_74|first = Gunnar|last = Carlsson|first2 = Gurjeet|last2 = Singh|first3 = Afra|last3 = Zomorodian|editor-first = Yingfei|editor-last = Dong|editor-first2 = Ding-Zhu|editor-last2 = Du|editor-first3 = Oscar|editor-last3 = Ibarra}}</ref> After then, many other algorithms have been proposed, based on such concepts as discrete morse theory<ref>{{cite arXiv|title = Reducing complexes in multidimensional persistent homology theory|arxiv= 1310.8089|date = 2013-10-30|first = Madjid|last = Allili|first2 = Tomasz|last2 = Kaczynski|first3 = Claudia|last3 = Landi}}</ref> and finite sample estimating.<ref>Cavazza N, Ferri M, Landi C. Estimating multidimensional persistent homology through a finite sampling[J]. 2010.</ref>
=== Other persistences === The standard paradigm in TDA is often referred as '''sublevel persistence'''. Apart from multidimensional persistence, many works have been done to extend this special case.
==== Zigzag persistence ==== The nonzero maps in persistence module are restricted by the preorder relationship in the category. However, mathematicians have found that the unanimity of direction is not essential to many results. "The philosophical point is that the decomposition theory of graph representations is somewhat independent of the orientation of the graph edges".<ref name="Carlsson 367–405">{{Cite journal|title = Zigzag Persistence|url = https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10208-010-9066-0|journal = Foundations of Computational Mathematics|date = 2010-04-21|issn = 1615-3375|pages = 367–405|volume = 10|issue = 4|doi = 10.1007/s10208-010-9066-0|first = Gunnar|last = Carlsson|first2 = Vin de|last2 = Silva}}</ref> Zigzag persistence is important to the theoretical side. The examples given in Carlsson's review paper to illustrate the importance of functorality all share some of its features.<ref name=":4" />
==== Extended persistence and levelset persistence ==== Some attempts is to lose the stricter restriction of the function.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Extending Persistence Using Poincaré and Lefschetz Duality|url = https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10208-008-9027-z|journal = Foundations of Computational Mathematics|date = 2008-04-04|issn = 1615-3375|pages = 79–103|volume = 9|issue = 1|doi = 10.1007/s10208-008-9027-z|first = David|last = Cohen-Steiner|first2 = Herbert|last2 = Edelsbrunner|first3 = John|last3 = Harer}}</ref> Please refer to the [[#Categorization and cosheaf|Categorization and cosheaf]] and [[#Impact on mathematics|Impact on mathematics]] sections for more information.
It's natural to extend persistence homology to other basic concepts in algebraic topology, such as cohomology and relative homology/cohomology.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Dualities in persistent (co)homology|url = http://iopscience.iop.org/article/10.1088/0266-5611/27/12/124003|journal = Inverse Problems|volume = 27|issue = 12|doi = 10.1088/0266-5611/27/12/124003|first = Vin|last = de Silva|first2 = Dmitriy|last2 = Morozov|first3 = Mikael|last3 = Vejdemo-Johansson|pages=124003|arxiv = 1107.5665|bibcode = 2011InvPr..27l4003D}}</ref> An interesting application is the computation of circular coordinates for a data set via the first persistent cohomology group.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Persistent Cohomology and Circular Coordinates|url = https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s00454-011-9344-x|journal = Discrete & Computational Geometry|date = 2011-03-30|issn = 0179-5376|pages = 737–759|volume = 45|issue = 4|doi = 10.1007/s00454-011-9344-x|first = Vin de|last = Silva|first2 = Dmitriy|last2 = Morozov|first3 = Mikael|last3 = Vejdemo-Johansson}}</ref>
==== Circular persistence ==== Normal persistence homology studies real-valued functions. The circle-valued map might be useful, "persistence theory for circle-valued maps promises to play the role for some vector fields as does the standard persistence theory for scalar fields", as commented in D. Burghelea et al.<ref name=":16">{{Cite journal|title = Topological Persistence for Circle-Valued Maps|url = https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s00454-013-9497-x|journal = Discrete & Computational Geometry|date = 2013-04-09|issn = 0179-5376|pages = 69–98|volume = 50|issue = 1|doi = 10.1007/s00454-013-9497-x|first = Dan|last = Burghelea|first2 = Tamal K.|last2 = Dey}}</ref> The main difference is that Jordan cells(very similar in format to the ones in linear algebra) are nontrivial in circle-valued functions, which would be zero in real-valued case, and combing with barcodes give the invariants of a tame map, under moderate conditions.<ref name=":16"/>
Two techniques they use are More-Novikov theory<ref>Novikov S P. Quasiperiodic structures in topology[C]//Topological methods in modern mathematics, Proceedings of the symposium in honor of John Milnor’s sixtieth birthday held at the State University of New York, Stony Brook, New York. 1991: 223-233.</ref> and graph representation theory.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Handbook of Graph Theory|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=mKkIGIea_BkC|publisher = CRC Press|date = 2004-06-02|isbn = 9780203490204|first = Jonathan L.|last = Gross|first2 = Jay|last2 = Yellen}}</ref> More recent results can be found in D. Burghelea et al.<ref>{{cite arXiv|title = Topology of angle valued maps, bar codes and Jordan blocks|arxiv= 1303.4328|date = 2015-06-04|first = Dan|last = Burghelea|first2 = Stefan|last2 = Haller}}</ref> For example, the tameness requirement can be replaced by the much weaker condition, continuous.
==== Persistence with torsion ==== The proof of the structure theorem relies on the base domain being field, so not many attempts have been made on persistence homology with torsion. Frosini defined a pseudometric on this specific module and proved its stability.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Stable Comparison of Multidimensional Persistent Homology Groups with Torsion|url = https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10440-012-9769-0|journal = Acta Applicandae Mathematicae|date = 2012-06-23|issn = 0167-8019|pages = 43–54|volume = 124|issue = 1|doi = 10.1007/s10440-012-9769-0|first = Patrizio|last = Frosini|arxiv = 1012.4169}}</ref> One of its novelty is that it doesn't depend on some classification theory to define the metric.<ref name=":12" />
=== Categorification and cosheaves === One advantage of [[category theory]] is its ability to lift concrete results to a higher level, showing relationships between seemingly unconnected objects. Bubenik et al.<ref name=":8">{{Cite journal|title = Categorification of Persistent Homology|url = https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s00454-014-9573-x|journal = Discrete & Computational Geometry|date = 2014-01-28|issn = 0179-5376|pages = 600–627|volume = 51|issue = 3|doi = 10.1007/s00454-014-9573-x|first = Peter|last = Bubenik|first2 = Jonathan A.|last2 = Scott}}</ref> offers a short introduction of category theory fitted for TDA.
Category theory is the language of modern algebra, and has been widely used in the study of algebraic geometry and topology. It has been noted that "the key observation of <ref name=":1" /> is that the persistence diagram produced by <ref name=":7" /> depends only on the algebraic structure carried by this diagram."<ref name=":9">{{Cite journal|title = Metrics for Generalized Persistence Modules|url = https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10208-014-9229-5|journal = Foundations of Computational Mathematics|date = 2014-10-09|issn = 1615-3375|pages = 1501–1531|volume = 15|issue = 6|doi = 10.1007/s10208-014-9229-5|first = Peter|last = Bubenik|first2 = Vin de|last2 = Silva|first3 = Jonathan|last3 = Scott}}</ref> The use of category theory in TDA has proved to be fruitful.<ref name=":8" /><ref name=":9"/>
Following the notations made in Bubenik et al.,<ref name=":9"/> the '''indexing category''' <math display="inline">P</math> is any [[preordered set]] (not necessarily <math>\mathbb{N}</math> or <math>\mathbb{R}</math>), the target category <math>D</math> is any category (instead of the commonly used <math display="inline">\mathrm{Vect}_{\mathbb{F}}</math>), and [[functor]]s <math display="inline">P \to D</math> are called '''generalized persistence modules''' in <math>D</math>, over <math display="inline">P</math>.
One advantage of using category theory in TDA is a clearer understanding of concepts and the discovery of new relationships between proofs. Take two examples for illustration. The understanding of the correspondence between interleaving and matching is of huge importance, since matching has been the method used in the beginning (modified from Morse theory). A summary of works can be found in Vin de Silva et al.<ref name=":21">{{Cite journal|title = Geometry in the Space of Persistence Modules|url = http://doi.acm.org/10.1145/2462356.2462402|publisher = ACM|journal = Proceedings of the Twenty-ninth Annual Symposium on Computational Geometry|date = 2013-01-01|location = New York, NY, USA|isbn = 978-1-4503-2031-3|pages = 397–404|series = SoCG '13|doi = 10.1145/2462356.2462402|first = Vin|last = de Silva|first2 = Vidit|last2 = Nanda}}</ref> Many theorems can be proved much more easily in a more intuitive setting.<ref name=":12" /> Another example is the relationship between the construction of different complexes from point clouds. It has long been noticed that Čech and Vietoris-Rips complexes are related. Specifically, <math>V_r(X) \subset C_{\sqrt{2}r}(X) \subset V_{2r}(X)</math>.<ref name=":5" /> The essential relationship between Cech and Rips complexes can be seen much more clearly in categorical language.<ref name=":21" />
The language of category theory also helps cast results in terms recognizable to the broader mathematical community. Bottleneck distance is widely used in TDA because of the results on stability with respect to the bottleneck distance.<ref name=":11" /><ref name=":17" /> In fact, the interleaving distance is the [[Initial and terminal objects|terminal object]] in a poset category of stable metrics on multidimensional persistence modules in a [[Field (mathematics)|prime field]].<ref name=":12">{{Cite journal|title = The Theory of the Interleaving Distance on Multidimensional Persistence Modules|url = https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10208-015-9255-y|journal = Foundations of Computational Mathematics|date = 2015-03-24|issn = 1615-3375|pages = 613–650|volume = 15|issue = 3|doi = 10.1007/s10208-015-9255-y|first = Michael|last = Lesnick}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|title = Natural Pseudo-Distance and Optimal Matching between Reduced Size Functions|url = https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10440-008-9332-1|journal = Acta Applicandae Mathematicae|date = 2008-10-14|issn = 0167-8019|pages = 527–554|volume = 109|issue = 2|doi = 10.1007/s10440-008-9332-1|first = Michele|last = d’Amico|first2 = Patrizio|last2 = Frosini|first3 = Claudia|last3 = Landi}}</ref>
[[Sheaf (mathematics)|Sheaves]], a central concept in modern [[algebraic geometry]], are intrinsically related to category theory. Roughly speaking, [[Sheaf (mathematics)|sheaves]] are the mathematical tool for understanding how local information determines global information. Justin Curry regards level set persistence as the study of [[Fiber (mathematics)|fibers]]<nowiki/> of continuous functions. The objects that he studies are very similar to those by MAPPER, but with sheaf theory as the theoretical foundation.<ref name=":3" /> Although no breakthrough in the theory of TDA has yet used sheaf theory, it is promising since there are many beautiful theorems in algebraic geometry relating to sheaf theory. For example, a natural theoretical question is whether different filtration methods result in the same output.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Filtrations induced by continuous functions|url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0166864113001892|journal = Topology and its Applications|date = 2013-08-01|pages = 1413–1422|volume = 160|issue = 12|doi = 10.1016/j.topol.2013.05.013|first = B.|last = Di Fabio|first2 = P.|last2 = Frosini}}</ref>
=== Stability === Stability is of central importance to data analysis, since real data carry noises. By usage of category theory, Bubenik et al. have distinguished between soft and hard stability theorems, and proved that soft cases are formal.<ref name=":9"/> Specifically, general workflow of TDA is {| class="wikitable" |data |<math>\stackrel{F}{\longrightarrow}</math> |topological persistence module |<math>\stackrel{H}{\longrightarrow}</math> |algebraic persistence module |<math>\stackrel{J}{\longrightarrow}</math> |discrete invariant |} The soft stability theorem asserts that <math>HF</math> is [[Lipschitz continuity|Lipschitz continuous]], and the hard stability theorem asserts that <math>J</math> is Lipschitz continuous.
Bottleneck distance is widely used in TDA. The isometry theorem asserts that the '''interleaving distance''' <math>d_I</math> is equal to the bottleneck distance.<ref name=":12" /> Bubenik et al. have abstracted the definition to that between functors <math>F,G: P\to D</math> when <math display="inline">P</math> is equipped with a sublinear projection or superlinear family, in which still remains a pseudometric.<ref name=":9"/> Considering the magnificent characters of interleaving distance,<ref>{{cite arXiv|title = Multidimensional Interleavings and Applications to Topological Inference|arxiv= 1206.1365|date = 2012-06-06|first = Michael|last = Lesnick}}</ref> here we introduce the general definition of interleaving distance(instead of the first introduced one):<ref name=":11" /> Let <math>\Gamma, K \in \mathrm{Trans_P}</math> (a function from <math display="inline">P</math> to <math display="inline">P</math> which is monotone and satisfies <math>x \leq \Gamma(x)</math> for all <math display="inline">x\in P</math>). A <math>(\Gamma, K)</math>-interleaving between F and G consists of natural transformations <math>\varphi: F \Rightarrow G\Gamma</math> and <math>\psi: G \Rightarrow FK</math>, such that <math>(\psi\Gamma)=\varphi F\eta_{K\Gamma}</math> and <math>(\varphi\Gamma)=\psi G\eta_{\Gamma K}</math>.
The two main results are<ref name=":9"/> * Let <math display="inline">P</math> be a preordered set with a sublinear projection or superlinear family. Let <math display="inline">H:D \to E</math> be a functor between arbitrary categories <math display="inline">D,E</math>. Then for any two functors <math display="inline">F,G:P\to D</math>, we have <math display="inline">d_I(HF,HG) \leq d_I(F,G)</math>. * Let <math display="inline">P</math> be a poset of a metric space <math display="inline">Y</math> , <math display="inline">X</math> be a topological space. And let<math display="inline">f,g:X\to Y</math> (not necessarily continuous) be functions, and <math display="inline">F,G</math> to be the corresponding persistence diagram. Then <math>d_I(F,G) \leq d_{\infty}(f,g):=\sup_{x\in X}d_Y(f(x),g(x))</math>. These two results summarize many results on stability of different models of persistence.
For the stability theorem of multidimensional persistence, please refer to the subsection of persistence.
=== Structure theorem === The structure theorem is of central importance to TDA; as commented by G. Carlsson, "what makes homology useful as a discriminator between topological spaces is the fact that there is a classification theorem for finitely generated abelian groups."<ref name=":4">{{Cite journal|title = Topology and data|url = http://www.ams.org/bull/2009-46-02/S0273-0979-09-01249-X/|journal = Bulletin of the American Mathematical Society|date = 2009-01-01|issn = 0273-0979|pages = 255–308|volume = 46|issue = 2|doi = 10.1090/S0273-0979-09-01249-X|first = Gunnar|last = Carlsson}}</ref> (see the [[fundamental theorem of finitely generated abelian groups]]).
The main argument used in the proof of the original structure theorem is the standard [[structure theorem for finitely generated modules over a principal ideal domain]].<ref name=":1" /> However, this argument fails if the indexing set is <math>(\mathbb{R},\leq)</math>.<ref name=":4" />
In general, not every persistence module can be decomposed into intervals.<ref name="Chazal">{{cite arXiv|title = The structure and stability of persistence modules|arxiv= 1207.3674|date = 2012-07-16|first = Frederic|last = Chazal|first2 = Vin|last2 = de Silva|first3 = Marc|last3 = Glisse|first4 = Steve|last4 = Oudot}}</ref> Many attempts have been made at relaxing the restrictions of the original structure theorem.{{Clarify|date=December 2015}} The case for pointwise finite-dimensional persistence modules indexed by a locally finite subset of <math>\mathbb{R}</math> is solved based on the work of Webb.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Decomposition of graded modules|url = http://www.ams.org/proc/1985-094-04/S0002-9939-1985-0792261-6/|journal = Proceedings of the American Mathematical Society|date = 1985-01-01|issn = 0002-9939|pages = 565–571|volume = 94|issue = 4|doi = 10.1090/S0002-9939-1985-0792261-6|first = Cary|last = Webb}}</ref> The most notable result is done by Crawley-Boevey, which solved the case of <math>\mathbb{R}</math>. Crawley-Boevey's theorem states that any pointwise finite-dimensional persistence module is a direct sum of interval modules.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Decomposition of pointwise finite-dimensional persistence modules|url = http://www.worldscientific.com/doi/pdf/10.1142/S0219498815500668|journal = Journal of Algebra and Its Applications|volume = 14|issue = 05|doi = 10.1142/s0219498815500668|first = William|last = Crawley-Boevey|pages=1550066}}</ref>
To understand the definition of his theorem, some concepts need introducing. An '''interval''' in <math>(\mathbb{R},\leq)</math> is defined as a subset <math>I \subset \mathbb{R}</math> having the property that if <math>r, t \in I</math> and if there is an <math>s \in \mathbb{R}</math> such that <math>r \leq s \leq t</math>, then <math>s\in I</math> as well. An '''interval module''' <math>k_I</math> assigns to each element <math>s\in I</math> the vector space <math>k</math> and assigns the zero vector space to elements in <math>\mathbb{R} / I</math>. All maps <math>\rho_s^t</math> are the zero map, unless <math>s,t \in I</math> and <math>s\leq t</math>, in which case <math>\rho_s^t</math> is the identity map.<ref name=":3" /> Interval modules are indecomposable.<ref name=":13">{{cite arXiv|title = The observable structure of persistence modules|arxiv= 1405.5644|date = 2014-05-22|first = Frederic|last = Chazal|first2 = William|last2 = Crawley-Boevey|first3 = Vin|last3 = de Silva}}</ref>
Although the result of Crawley-Boevey is a very powerful theorem, it still doesn't extend to the q-tame case.<ref name="Chazal"/> A persistence module is '''q-tame''' if the rank of <math>\rho_s^t</math> is finite for all <math>s\leq t</math>. There are examples of q-tame persistence modules that fail to be pointwise finite.<ref>{{cite arXiv|title = A subset of Euclidean space with large Vietoris-Rips homology|arxiv= 1210.4097|date = 2012-10-15|first = Jean-Marie|last = Droz}}</ref> However, it turns out that a similar structure theorem still holds if the features that exist only at one index value are removed.<ref name=":13" /> This holds because the infinite dimensional parts at each index value do not persist, due to the finite-rank condition.<ref name=":18">Weinberger S. What is... persistent homology?[J]. Notices of the AMS, 2011, 58(1): 36-39.</ref> Formally, the observable category <math>\mathrm{Ob}</math> is defined as <math>\mathrm{Pers}/\mathrm{Eph}</math>, in which <math>\mathrm{Eph}</math> denotes the full subcategory of <math>\mathrm{Pers}</math> whose objects are the ephemeral modules (<math>\rho^t_s=0</math> whenever <math>s < t</math>).<ref name=":13" />
Note that the extended results listed here do not apply to zigzag persistence, since the analogue of a zigzag persistence module over <math>\mathbb R</math> is not immediately obvious.
=== Statistics === Real data is always finite, and so its study requires us to take stochasticity into account. Statistical analysis gives us the ability to separate true features of the data from artifacts introduced by random noise. Persistent homology has no inherent mechanism to distinguish between low-probability features and high-probability features.
One way to apply statistics to topological data analysis is to study the statistical properties of topological features of point clouds. The study of random simplicial complexes offers some insight into statistical topology. K. Turner et al.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Fréchet Means for Distributions of Persistence Diagrams|url = https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s00454-014-9604-7|journal = Discrete & Computational Geometry|date = 2014-07-12|issn = 0179-5376|pages = 44–70|volume = 52|issue = 1|doi = 10.1007/s00454-014-9604-7|first = Katharine|last = Turner|first2 = Yuriy|last2 = Mileyko|first3 = Sayan|last3 = Mukherjee|first4 = John|last4 = Harer}}</ref> offers a summary of work in this vein.
Another way is to study probability distributions on the persistence space. The persistence space <math>B_{\infty}</math> is <math>\coprod_n B_{n}/ \backsim</math>, where <math>B_{n}</math> is the space of all barcodes containing exactly <math>n</math> intervals and the equivalences are <math>\{[x_1,y_1],[x_2,y_2],...,[x_n,y_n]\} \backsim \{[x_1,y_1],[x_2,y_2],...,[x_{n-1},y_{n-1}]\}</math> if <math>x_n = y_n</math>.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|title = Topological pattern recognition for point cloud data|url = http://journals.cambridge.org/article_S0962492914000051|journal = Acta Numerica|date = 2014-05-01|issn = 1474-0508|pages = 289–368|volume = 23|doi = 10.1017/S0962492914000051|first = Gunnar|last = Carlsson}}</ref> This space is fairly complicated; for example, it is not complete under the bottleneck metric. The first attempt made to study it is by Y. Mileyko et al.<ref name=":20">{{Cite journal|title = Probability measures on the space of persistence diagrams|url = http://iopscience.iop.org/article/10.1088/0266-5611/27/12/124007/meta|journal = Inverse Problems|date = 2011-11-10|issn = 0266-5611|pages = 124007|volume = 27|issue = 12|doi = 10.1088/0266-5611/27/12/124007|first = Yuriy|last = Mileyko|first2 = Sayan|last2 = Mukherjee|first3 = John|last3 = Harer|bibcode = 2011InvPr..27l4007M}}</ref> The space of persistence diagrams <math>D_p</math> in their paper is defined as <math display="block">D_p := \left\{d | \sum_{x\in d}\left(2\inf_{y \in \Delta}\lVert x-y \rVert\right)^p\right\}</math>where <math>\Delta</math> is the diagonal line in <math>\mathbb{R}^2</math>. A nice property is that <math>D_p</math> is complete and separable in the Wasserstein metric <math>W_p(u,v)=\left(\inf_{\gamma\in \Gamma(u,v)}\int_{\mathbb{X}\times \mathbb{X}} \rho^p(x,y)\mathrm{d}\gamma(x,y)\right)^{\frac{1}{p}}</math>. Expectation, variance, and conditional probability can be defined in the [[Fréchet mean|Fréchet sense]]. This allows many statistical tools to be ported to TDA. Works on [[Null hypothesis significance testing|null hypothesis significance test]],<ref>{{cite arXiv|title = Hypothesis Testing for Topological Data Analysis|arxiv= 1310.7467|date = 2013-10-28|first = Andrew|last = Robinson|first2 = Katharine|last2 = Turner}}</ref> [[confidence interval|confidence intervals]],<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Confidence sets for persistence diagrams|url = http://projecteuclid.org/euclid.aos/1413810729|journal = The Annals of Statistics|date = 2014-12-01|issn = 0090-5364|pages = 2301–2339|volume = 42|issue = 6|doi = 10.1214/14-AOS1252|first = Brittany Terese|last = Fasy|first2 = Fabrizio|last2 = Lecci|first3 = Alessandro|last3 = Rinaldo|first4 = Larry|last4 = Wasserman|first5 = Sivaraman|last5 = Balakrishnan|first6 = Aarti|last6 = Singh}}</ref> and robust estimates<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Robust Statistics, Hypothesis Testing, and Confidence Intervals for Persistent Homology on Metric Measure Spaces|url = https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10208-014-9201-4|journal = Foundations of Computational Mathematics|date = 2014-05-15|issn = 1615-3375|pages = 745–789|volume = 14|issue = 4|doi = 10.1007/s10208-014-9201-4|first = Andrew J.|last = Blumberg|first2 = Itamar|last2 = Gal|first3 = Michael A.|last3 = Mandell|first4 = Matthew|last4 = Pancia}}</ref> are notable steps.
Persistence landscapes, introduced by Peter Bubenik, are a different way to represent of barcodes, more amenable to statistical analysis.<ref>{{cite arXiv|title = Statistical topological data analysis using persistence landscapes|arxiv= 1207.6437|date = 2012-07-26|first = Peter|last = Bubenik}}</ref> The '''persistence landscape''' of a persistent module <math>M</math> is defined as a function <math>\lambda:\mathbb{N}\times\mathbb{R}\to \bar{\mathbb{R}}</math>, <math>\lambda(k,t):=\sup(m\geq 0|\beta^{t-m,t-m}\geq k)</math>, where <math>\bar{\mathbb{R}}</math> denotes the [[Extended real number line|extended real line]] and <math>\beta^{a,b}=\mathrm{dim}(\mathrm{im}(M(a\leq b)))</math>. The space of persistence landscapes is very nice: it inherits all good properties of barcode representation (stability, easy representation, etc.), but statistical quantities can be readily defined, and some problems in Y. Mileyko et al.'s work, such as the non-uniqueness of expectations,<ref name=":20"/> can be overcome. Effective algorithms for computation with persistence landscapes are available.<ref>{{cite journal|title = A persistence landscapes toolbox for topological statistics|arxiv= 1501.00179|date = 2014-12-31|first = Peter|last = Bubenik|first2 = Pawel|last2 = Dlotko|doi=10.1016/j.jsc.2016.03.009|volume=78|journal=Journal of Symbolic Computation|pages=91–114}}</ref> Another approach is to use revised persistence, which is image, kernel and cokernel persistence.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Persistent Homology for Kernels, Images, and Cokernels|url = http://epubs.siam.org/doi/pdf/10.1137/1.9781611973068.110|pages = 1011–1020|doi = 10.1137/1.9781611973068.110|first = David|last = Cohen-Steiner|first2 = Herbert|last2 = Edelsbrunner|first3 = John|last3 = Harer|first4 = Dmitriy|last4 = Morozov}}</ref>

=== Characteristics of TDA in applications === [http://www.ayasdi.com Ayasdi] is a data analysis company relying heavily on TDA, cofounded by a number of leading researchers in the field. There are several notable interesting features of the recent applications of TDA: # '''Combining tools from several branches of mathematics'''. Besides the obvious need for algebra and topology, partial differential equations,<ref>{{cite arXiv|title = Objective-oriented Persistent Homology|arxiv= 1412.2368|date = 2014-12-07|first = Bao|last = Wang|first2 = Guo-Wei|last2 = Wei}}</ref> algebraic geometry,<ref name="Carlsson 71–93" /> presentation theory,<ref name="Carlsson 367–405" /> statistics, combinatorics, and Riemannian geometry<ref name=":18" /> have all found use in TDA. # '''Quantitative analysis'''. Topology is considered to be very soft since many concepts are invariant under homotopy. However, persistent topology is able to record the birth (appearance) and death (disappearance) of topological features, thus extra geometric information is embedded in it. One evidence in theory is a partially positive result on the uniqueness of reconstruction of curves;<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Uniqueness of models in persistent homology: the case of curves|url = http://iopscience.iop.org/article/10.1088/0266-5611/27/12/124005 |doi = 10.1088/0266-5611/27/12/124005 | volume=27|journal=Inverse Problems|pages=124005|first = Patrizio|last = Frosini|first2 = Claudia|last2 = Landi|arxiv=1012.5783|bibcode=2011InvPr..27l4005F}}</ref> two in application are on the quantitative analysis of Fullerene stability and quantitative analysis of [[self-similarity]], separately.<ref name=":6" /><ref>{{Cite journal|title = Persistent homology for the quantitative prediction of fullerene stability|url = http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/jcc.23816/abstract|journal = Journal of Computational Chemistry|date = 2015-03-05|issn = 1096-987X|pmc = 4324100|pmid = 25523342|pages = 408–422|volume = 36|issue = 6|doi = 10.1002/jcc.23816|first = Kelin|last = Xia|first2 = Xin|last2 = Feng|first3 = Yiying|last3 = Tong|first4 = Guo Wei|last4 = Wei}}</ref> # '''The role of short persistence'''. Short persistence has also been found to be useful, despite the common belief that noise is the cause of the phenomena.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Persistent homology analysis of protein structure, flexibility, and folding|url = http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cnm.2655/abstract|journal = International Journal for Numerical Methods in Biomedical Engineering|date = 2014-08-01|issn = 2040-7947|pmc = 4131872|pmid = 24902720|pages = 814–844|volume = 30|issue = 8|doi = 10.1002/cnm.2655|first = Kelin|last = Xia|first2 = Guo-Wei|last2 = Wei}}</ref> This is interesting to the mathematical theory. One of the main fields of data analysis today is [[machine learning]]. Some examples of machine learning in TDA can be found in Adcock et al.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = The ring of algebraic functions on persistence bar codes|url = http://intlpress.com/site/pub/files/_fulltext/journals/hha/2016/0018/0001/HHA-2016-0018-0001-a021.pdf|journal=Homology, Homotopy, and Applications|date = 2016-05-31|pages = 381–402|volume = 18|issue = 1|doi = 10.4310/hha.2016.v18.n1.a21|first = Aaron|last = Adcock|first2 = Erik|last2 = Carlsson|first3 = Gunnar|last3=Carlsson}}</ref> A [http://www.birs.ca/events/2012/5-day-workshops/12w5081 conference] is dedicated to the link between TDA and machine learning. In order to apply tools from machine leaning, the information obtained from TDA should be represented in vector form. An ongoing and promising attempt is the persistence landscape discussed above. Another attempt uses the concept of persistence images.<ref>{{cite arXiv|title = Persistence Images: An Alternative Persistent Homology Representation|arxiv= 1507.06217|date = 2015-07-22|first = Sofya|last = Chepushtanova|first2 = Tegan|last2 = Emerson|first3 = Eric|last3 = Hanson|first4 = Michael|last4 = Kirby|first5 = Francis|last5 = Motta|first6 = Rachel|last6 = Neville|first7 = Chris|last7 = Peterson|first8 = Patrick|last8 = Shipman|first9 = Lori|last9 = Ziegelmeier}}</ref> However, one problem of this method is the loss of stability, since the hard stability theorem depends on the barcode representation.
=== Impact on mathematics === Topological data analysis and persistent homology have had impacts on [[Morse theory]]. Morse theory has played a very important role in the theory of TDA, including on computation. Some work in persistent homology has extended results about Morse functions to tame functions or, even to continuous functions. A forgotten result of R. Deheuvels long before the invention of persistent homology extends Morse theory to all continuous functions.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Topologie D'Une Fonctionnelle|journal = Annals of Mathematics|date = 1955-01-01|pages = 13–72|volume = 61|series = Second Series|issue = 1|doi = 10.2307/1969619|first = Rene|last = Deheuvels|jstor=1969619}}</ref>
One recent result is that the category of [[Reeb graph]]s is equivalent to a particular class of cosheaf.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Categorified Reeb graphs|journal=Discrete and Computational Geometry|first=Vin|last=de Silva|first2=Elizabeth|last2=Munch|first3=Amit|last3 = Patel|doi=10.1007/s00454-016-9763-9|url=https://doi.org/10.1007/s00454-016-9763-9|date=2016-04-13}}</ref> This is motivated by theoretical work in TDA, since the Reeb graph is related to Morse theory and MAPPER is derived from it. The proof of this theorem relies on the interleaving distance.
It is evident to mathematicians that persistent homology is closely related to [[spectral sequence]]s.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Surveys on Discrete and Computational Geometry: Twenty Years Later : AMS-IMS-SIAM Joint Summer Research Conference, June 18-22, 2006, Snowbird, Utah|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=ecUbCAAAQBAJ|publisher = American Mathematical Soc.|date = 2008-01-01|isbn = 9780821842393|first = Jacob E.|last = Goodman}}</ref> Zigzag persistence may turn out to be of theoretical importance to spectral sequences.
